firstTime.scenario: Help! I ordered this tuna poke bowl with avocado and spicy mayo, but I have no clue what wine to get. The server is coming back and I'm totally lost!

option1Wine.feedbackText: Oops! Cabernet's bold tannins would completely overpower the delicate tuna. Raw fish needs something much lighter and more acidic to complement its clean flavors.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Perfect choice! Sauvignon Blanc's crisp acidity and citrus notes perfectly complement raw fish, while its clean finish won't compete with the delicate tuna flavors.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Not bad, but a bit heavy. While Chardonnay works with fish, an oaked version might mask the tuna's delicate flavor. The poke bowl's freshness calls for something crisper.

firstTime.scenario: I'm staring at this menu and I ordered the grilled ribeye steak with garlic butter. Everyone's talking about wine but I literally don't know where to start. What should I ask for?

option1Wine.feedbackText: Too delicate! Riesling's light body and sweetness can't stand up to a rich, fatty ribeye. You need a wine with enough tannins and body to cut through the beef's richness.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Interesting choice, but not ideal. While the acidity could cut fat, Sauvignon Blanc lacks the body and tannins needed to complement the meat's robust flavors.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Excellent! Cabernet's bold tannins and full body are perfect for ribeye. The wine's structure cuts through the fat while its dark fruit flavors complement the meat's richness.

firstTime.scenario: So I got this Caesar salad with grilled chicken because I'm trying to be healthy-ish, but now they're asking about wine and I'm like... help? What goes with salad?

option1Wine.feedbackText: Decent thinking with the chicken, but Caesar's anchovy dressing and parmesan create salty, briny flavors that pair better with crisp white wines than light reds.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Smart choice! Chardonnay's body handles the chicken while its acidity cuts through the creamy Caesar dressing. The wine's richness complements the parmesan perfectly.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Too heavy! Merlot's dark fruit flavors would clash with the Caesar's briny, garlicky profile. Salads with creamy dressings need wines with good acidity.

remedial.scenario: I keep messing up wine choices! I have grilled salmon with lemon herbs and I really don't want to look stupid again. Please help me get this right!

option1Wine.feedbackText: Perfect! You're learning! Sauvignon Blanc's herbaceous notes echo the herbs, while its acidity enhances the lemon and complements the salmon's delicate flavor.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Remember the basic rule: delicate fish needs delicate wine. Cabernet's tannins and boldness would completely overwhelm the subtle salmon flavors.

remedial.scenario: Last chance to prove I can do this! I ordered a big juicy burger with bacon and cheese. I want to show I understand wine pairing now!

option1Wine.feedbackText: Think about the weight! A rich, fatty burger needs a wine with enough body and tannins to cut through all that richness. Riesling is too light and delicate.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Excellent! You've got it! Merlot's medium body and soft tannins are perfect for burgers - rich enough to complement the meat and fat, structured enough to cleanse the palate.
